document2:
eating disorders are complicated. they don’t exist in a vacuum. what feels like an incredibly intimate battle is the opposite. when you’re sick, every person in your life is too. nobody is untouched by your pain. and this is the heaviest burden.

i was 13 years old when my relationship with food, exercise, and my body turned toxic. i was an older sister, a daughter, a best friend, a teammate. yet all i ever thought about was me. i planned every meal out for weeks in advance. i wondered how many calories i burned walking to class. i tugged at the waistband of the jeans sliding off my hips, wanting more of me to disappear when there was nothing to spare. 

my sisters, my parents, my best friend, my teammates and coaches- they fell to the outskirts of my life. i had no time in my day to uphold relationships. how could i? when i passed every waking second running circles in my mind over a scoop of peanut butter i ate last week?

i isolated myself. my eating disorder was safe when nobody was around to challenge it. nobody to ask, “didn’t you already work out today?” or “why aren’t you eating?” or “are you okay?”. in the beginning i missed these people. i missed their love. but my ED promised me great things in their absence, so i let them go. 

i actively struggled with my ED for 5 years. 5 years of pain and misery and throwing fits and screaming matches. 5 years of running away from dinners in public. 5 years of skipping my sisters’ recitals and games, because i would be forced to eat or miss a workout. 5 years of projecting pain onto everyone, even though at the time this never crossed my mind. 

i thought because i physically isolated myself, that my ED was contained. but it spread like wildfire. i only know this in hindsight, and it hurts, to see colors where i only saw black and white. 

my family and friends hurt deeply for me. with me. my mom used to always say a mother is only as happy as her saddest child. to this day that moves me to tears. 

we never hurt alone, even if we try our best to do just that. if you can’t bring yourself to heal for YOU, then at the very least do it for someone else. i promise they feel your pain.
document3: Question: Do eating disorder thoughts still take up a lot of brain space and make you feel bad? What does that 95% stability look like and mean for you? I'm so hopeless about ever getting the thoughts to go even if physically I'm better now  Answer: Eating disorder thoughts still come and go. However they don’t take up much brain space and they generally don’t make me feel bad. I spot them for what they are and I reassure myself with a healthy thought.95% stability means 95% of my life feels recovered to me. 5% of me still does some disordered things which I ideally wouldn’t do, but I can live with them. Most of the time I eat regularly, adequately and flexibly. I’ve worked through so many behaviours and negative thought patterns in therapy that if any of them start, I can hear my therapist’s voice on that particular topic and I can channel it to take charge of my eating disorder tendencies.It’s not been a quick process and it’s taken a lot of effort and repetition and patience and hard work in therapy (by both T and me), plus lapses and steps backwards and ruptures. But gradually gradually it all starts to come together. I think an important thing is finding someone you can work through the thoughts with, even after you’re physically better. The thoughts hang around in your head if you can’t process through them, so saying them out loud to someone and being in a place in your relationship with that person that you are willing to allow their responses to change your brain is really healing and is a key to neural rewiring.

“I’d be so much happier if I looked like ✨them✨”… Don’t worry bestie, they don’t always look like the social media version of themselves either. I’m living proof of that 👀

The truth is, they have days where they feel like crap too. They have things they don’t like about themselves. They see themselves under the same harsh microscope that we all view ourselves under.

And when you’re having a hard time with your body image, you’re more likely to feel:
unmotivated, unhappy, negative, antisocial, unfulfilled, anxious to leave the house, unloveable, short-tempered, self-saboting, like you don’t want to eat well or workout… Because you’re coming from a place of hate, instead of love.

We always believe that in order to feel good, we have to CHANGE ourselves on the outside.

But you’re actually more likely to workout, eat well, be happy, confident, reach whatever goals you have & be motivated in life if you work on improving your body image instead! (not your body)

People with a positive body image are more likely to have good physical & mental health, because instead of punishing yourself with unrealistic, restrictive lifestyle changes & unkind thoughts that could lead to mental health conditions, such as EDs & depression, you’re more likely to WANT to look after your body in more sustainable, balanced ways.

The goal is not to change your body, it’s to change your mindset. When you do that, the rest will flow so effortlessly.

How does social media make you feel about yourself? Leave a 😍 if it makes you feel good & a 😵‍💫 if it leaves you feeling worse. Curate your space, your mental wellness is so important! Keep making choices for yourself out of love, you’ve got this! 💗

document5: “I belong deeply to myself.” - Warsan Shire Something I’ve learned in eating disorder treatment is that when I use the eating disorder, I am living in other people’s beliefs. See, the eating disorder behaviors are in line with messages I was given over the years by various people in my life telling me that I was unworthy, dirty, and broken. That I don’t deserve to take up space or have a voice or be seen. These messages came from outside of me and, not knowing any better, I internalized them as my own. When I destroy my body, I am taking on those people’s truths about who I am – and subsequently giving away all of my power to those people. And quite frankly, I am really freaking tired of being owned by other people. They don’t deserve to have that kind of control over my life. They don’t deserve to have their words and their beliefs holding power over my mind and my actions. When I use the eating disorder, my depression and hopelessness skyrocket because I am out of line with my values and beliefs, suppressing my Real Self and living in other people’s truths again. When I bring my behaviors in sign with my soul, the deepest, truest parts of me, the internal chaos and pain quiets down a little bit. It’s not easy by an means and it’s a battle everyday, but I want my power back. I want a life that is my own, not anyone else’s.

at 15 years old, i had to relearn nearly everything i knew about being human.
.
my eating disorder had turned me into a zombie, a machine. it drained me like a parasite. it stripped me of every last touch of life. i was empty, always empty. .
so when i finally began a true recovery, i had to leave this behind.
.
i had to relearn the simple things. how to walk across a room without growing lightheaded. how to climb stairs without taking a break to sit after each ascent upward. how to sit in a chair without my tailbone screaming with agony.
.
i had to relearn the things that human beings naturally seek out for their well-being. how to eat without a demon in my ear insisting i would self-combust for doing so. how to stay put when an anxiety attack whirled inside my stomach. why? because my sisters got to go for runs and my teammates got to go to practice and me? i wasn’t allowed to exercise for months.
.
i had to relearn the things that take you from existing to living. how to laugh again. how to accept an invitation for a meal out, one i couldn’t control, in order to mend broken relationships. how to follow my heart instead of my hyper-structured schedule. how to say yes, yes, yes to everything my eating disorder would have never allowed.
.
i had to relearn how to be selfless. how to heal myself so those who loved me could sleep at night. how to accept my body for how it looked and what it could do because it deserved better than a voice in my head. how to skip the gym, have a second lunch, embrace schedule changes in order to accommodate others in my life.
.
and i’m still learning. i’m learning how to love, how to receive love. how to accept. accept the life i’ve been given, the body i have, the way i look. how to be kind, how to stay stronger than the fleeting whispers of a disordered behavior from lifetimes ago. how to keep going when it feels crippling to do so.
.
recovery from an eating disorder is a lifelong pursuit, an intimate and emotional endeavor to find peace in your own heart. it is hard, it is taxing…but it is stabilizing, it is rewarding. it is the most humbling challenge i will ever take on, and for that i’m deeply grateful.

i used to make 3-ingredient vegan cookie dough all of the time in college-- it was the perfect budget/time friendly sweet treat. yesterday i decided to make some again for the first time in years, but was feeling ambitious and decided to bake it in the oven into bars…

and i’m *SO* glad i did. these cookie dough bars turned out way better than i was expecting!! like a soft-baked cookie without all of the work hahaha. think just 3 ingredients that are all nourishing and wholesome on their own but an absolute powerhouse when paired together. 

for the skeptics— no, you can’t taste the chickpeas :)

3-ingredient vegan chickpea cookie dough bars

ingredients:

- 1 can (15.5 oz) chickpeas, rinsed and drained
- 1/2 cup creamy salted peanut butter 
- 1/2 cup maple syrup
- pinch each of sea salt and baking powder
- chocolate chips/chopped chocolate for mixing in

directions:

preheat oven to 350 and prepare a brownie tin. add all of the ingredients to a blender (except chocolate) and blend until a thick, uniform batter forms. will be very thick but this is fine! stir through the chocolate by hand and transfer dough to the brownie tin. bake for 10-12 minutes or until golden brown. they’ll be soft in texture (like an under baked cookie). i let mine cool completely in the fridge for an hour or two before slicing. you can heat the bars up in the microwave if you’d like to eat them warm, but they’re delicious cold too :)

it’s really about time that i combined  two of my favorite foods— sandwiches and banana bread. between the glaze and roasted peanuts on top and the sweet jelly filling inside each slice, this loaf is on another level. 

if you’re like me and need a flavor break from all things pumpkin and apple, then you definitely should add this to your baking list this week! 

peanut butter & jelly banana bread

ingredients:

- 1/3 cup vegan butter, melted & cooled
- 1 /2 cup coconut sugar 
- 1/2 cup granulated sugar
- 2 large eggs
- splash of vanilla extract 
- 3 large ripe bananas, mashed

- 1/2 cup oat flour
-1 cup gluten free flour
- pinch of baking soda
- pinch of sea salt 

mix ins: 
- fruit jelly of choice
- dry roasted peanuts

heat oven to 350F and grease a loaf pan. in a bowl using a hand mixer, beat together the butter, sugar, eggs and vanilla until smooth. add the banana mash and mix until uniform. then fold in the dry ingredients and stir until smooth. fold peanuts and spoonfuls of jelly into the mix and transfer batter to the loaf pan. top with more peanuts and jelly (swirled around) and bake for 45-50 min. or until golden brown. let cool completely before glazing! for the glaze i just used powdered sugar, a splash of milk, and a small spoonful of jelly all mixed until uniform.

double stuffed jumbo vegan peanut butter cups

document1: Therapy 3.12.19 // writing the story  T said hi in quite a gentle tone of voice and I said hi back, and she said, here we are again. She asked me if I was ok, because she said I seemed a bit flat. I said no I’m ok. I was suddenly a bit tearful because it felt like she’d said hi so gently, as if she knew it was going to be a tough session, and the quietness in her voice caught me a bit unexpectedly.  “Do you have any things to talk about on your list today?” I shook my head “Ok so shall we talk about this story that you sent me?” I nodded and T pulled across a print out of it she had right there next to her. “How did it feel to write this?” “Uh…. well I didn’t set out to write that, what it turned out to be. I sat down to try and put into words something I had been thinking about.” “Ok, what were you trying to write?” “Uh… so at the end of last session, I said [insert a slightly confused and jarbled retelling of the conversation], and I think up till then I’d felt like you were kind of neutral on what went on in my childhood. Like, maybe those things happened but they probably weren’t really a big deal. But when you said what you said, I felt like you were on my side and maybe you did think some of the things that happened were wrong….” I tailed off, and T spoke up “Yes, you’re right. I do think some of the things were wrong” “Oh. Um so I was thinking about that and trying to put into words something about, uh, so I see families and children who come into foster care, and they generally have similarities in the situations of the families. Like they’re often struggling with money, one or both parents not working, relationship breakdown, complicated situations… and things go on at home that I think almost everyone would agree was wrong. And I was thinking I would say it’s wrong for those children to be subjected to those things. But it’s hard to think that maybe things - not so extreme, but still things - were going on in my family when it was not that sort of situation at all…. So I sat down to write that, but then when I started typing, I wrote that story instead.”
document2: Soooo tired. On my third cup of coffee (and the first was a double).  I just want my therapist. Something triggered the longing, but I can’t remember what right this minute. And then because I’m tired and just want to be looked after for a moment instead of doing all the looking after, the longing continued.  I’m trying to validate my feelings. It’s ok to feel like this, I know it’s because I’m feeling a bit emotionally and physically worn out. I’m thinking of the nurturing things T has said to me in the past and I’m telling myself them again. I know if I reached out to her she would reply, but I’m not in crisis so I think I can get my adult self to take care of little me - while still accepting that it’s ok to wish T were here to do it.  Times like this bring up the paradox and limits of the therapy relationship. I had to get attached to my therapist in order to let my defences down and do the deep healing work. But then that attachment only gets seen for 50 mins a week, and the rest of the week I have to cope with it on my own *sigh*. Not fair.
document3: Therapy 05.05.20 // after the bombshell  I managed to not completely shut down. T explained that she’d put a statement on her website about not taking new clients - she wondered if I’d seen it - and she just felt very aware that it was out there but it had gone unspoken between us, and so she wanted to bring it up so we could talk about it.  I had seen her statement, but I’d presumed she just wasn’t taking any new clients during lockdown because it was difficult to start a new therapeutic relationship online. So I hadn’t thought about it any further than that.  T then said lots of lovely things to me. I don’t know if you’d call it damage limitation, but it was like she’d dropped this bombshell about retiring on me, and now she was quickly trying to catch me before I fell.  “I will never forget you Faith. You will always have a place in my heart. I really enjoy working with you. I do! I never think, oh no I have to see Faith today. You work so hard in therapy and you are always thinking… working on things. I know it’s a therapeutic relationship that we have, but you can’t have a real therapeutic relationship without having some elements of a normal relationship too. That’s the privilege of a therapeutic relationship. In fact, it can be deeper than a normal relationship because you have the boundaries in place to make it safe to go deeper than you usually would be able to.” I listened to her and tried to let myself absorb all her words. The battle between shutting down or staying present was still going to and fro inside me. Gradually as she kept talking, repeating the same things, her voice soothed me and I started to feel calmer internally. After T had stopped talking, there was a pause. “So, what’s going on in your head now?” I think I said something about how at least if T made the decision to end therapy, then I wouldn’t feel regret for ending therapy myself. What if I decided to end, and then something happened and I needed T again. I’d be kicking myself. Whereas this way I would know I’d had no choice. T squinted at me and said she wasn’t sure that was very therapeutic. To be honest, I think I felt a little bit gleeful. Maybe it’s not therapeutic but it’s what you’ve done T. I said I felt a little bit stubborn, “Well, now I don’t have to make the decision myself about when to end”. T looked at me thoughtfully and said “hmm I think that’s important… I’m not sure right now quite how, I’ll have to have a think about it…”  We were coming to the end of the session and T said “I get the feeling that you were about an 8 or a 9 in terms of having a wobble when I told you, but how would you feel now?” I considered, “Maybe a 4 or 5” “Ok that’s good, it’s come down a bit then. Was I accurate in saying an 8 or a 9?” “Uh… yes… and I was having a wobble too in that I was nearly shutting down…. A few years ago I would have completely shut down for the rest of the session if you told me something like that. But I managed not to today.” T smiled and said I had done really well and it was good that I had noticed how much progress I had made.

document5: Question: So I have a question.  Do you ever feel like there's two versions of you in therapy (adult vs child) and that they're responding two different ways?  I emailed my therapist that I had made the dean's list (3.5+ GPA (Or A-B average)) this semester and she told me that I did really good and that that was amazing.  The week before (we're every other week right now and I see her Tuesday) we talked about how I have such a hard time with praise (can't be praised/praise myself for what is 'expected' of me because parents always discounting my achievements, etc (long trauma history for me of emotional abuse from them, some still ongoing).  My adult self didn't respond to her email but tonight I'm feeling very emotional and vulnerable and I want to send her an email apologizing and saying she shouldn't have responded because I'm supposed to make dean's list and that I'm sorry for bothering her and that I'm sorry if I'm too much.  Adult me stopped me from sending it.  What do I do?  Do I send the email?  Why do I feel like this?  It feels so stupid. Answer: Hi anon, sorry I know I am very slow replying to this message. What did you do? Did you send the email?Yes I very often feel like there’s two versions of me in therapy, the adult and the child. Sometimes when T is saying something to me that makes my adult self squirm or want to discount, such as praise, I try and quiet that part of my mind and think “let the child in me hear this”. And I sit and listen and absorb what T is saying and believe that some part of me deep down is taking it in even if that other noisy bit of my brain is thinking bah! this isn’t for you! It’s kind of like stepping out of my own way and letting T in to do stuff in my brain. A person has to build up enough trust in their therapist to allow them to do that though.We feel like this because as children we got wrong or mixed messages that we made sense of the best way we could but that weren’t right. Now those beliefs aren’t serving us well and can get in our own way, so if we want to be free to live more authentic lives we need to undo those false beliefs and replace them with true ones.

That no matter how many stories I tell her, there will always be more and there will always be a balance between good times and bad times that is just impossible to recreate accurately. Partly because I can never tell her everything and partly because even the things I tell her are remembering through the eyes of myself as a child. T nodded and said that was true.  We were out of time to take it any further. While I was still sat contemplating what I’d just said, T said “let’s have a mad five minutes to finish and talk about lighter things”. document9: Therapy 08.09.20 // do you want brutal honesty?  I turned up to this therapy session a little bit nervous but feeling like I had stuff to talk about. The week before, therapy had ended in a difficult place because I’d just told T I felt like she was always defending my parents and on their side - and then we ran out of time. So T referred to that first thing in a roundabout way, and I gave her a lopsided smile because we were on the same page. T said “I can see from your smile that you remember what we were talking about. Are you ok to talk about that, or do you have something else to talk about?” I said that I wanted to carry on talking about it.  “Ok, so I know you said that you felt like I am often defending your parents. The dilemma I have is that in any sort of counselling or therapy, it’s really important that the client comes to their own conclusions about things - uh I wouldn’t have been able to have this conversation with you a few years ago, but I think now we can talk about this?” I nodded. T continued, “So it’s been important I let you come to your own conclusions, but maybe you’re ready for me to be a bit more honest about my thoughts?” I watched her face carefully. She smiled and said “It depends how brutally honest you want me to be?…. Hmm well, I suppose that’s hard for you to answer because you don’t know what I’m going to say!…” My first thought was that yes, I wanted to hear her brutally honest opinion, because it’s so hard to know what is “normal” or “not normal” when it’s just what you’ve always known. But then I panicked and thought what if her brutally honest opinion is a bit too shocking to hear right now, am I ready for that?, and so I hesitated. I wasn’t sure I was ready to hear it all, after all.

You are not worth “more” if there is “less” of you. Your worth & happiness doesn’t increase if others think you are: beautiful, productive, successful, rich, the best or the smartest.

What matters isn't what your life looks like. It's what your life FEELS like. It’s what YOU think of you.

Whenever I’ve had a bad body image day (or negative self-talk day) it’s usually triggered by a single negative thought that snowballs into more… For e.g. let’s say you’re scrolling through social media comparing yourself to someone — from that single negative thought, the floodgates open… 

Now you have two choices, you can 1️⃣ acknowledge the way you’re speaking to yourself, nip it in the bud & consciously choose to fill your mind with kinder thoughts

OR 2️⃣ you can lean into that judgemental voice, continue to sabotage yourself, let those feelings fester & leak into other aspects of your life.

The way you speak to yourself matters!!! YOU have the power to choose which path you take. This is a concept I never really knew existed until I started taking back that power & respecting myself (& my body) more. It didn’t come naturally at first, but the more you consciously lean into those gentler thoughts, the easier it becomes to protect your peace & create a safe space in your own mind.

I also understand that sometimes we need extra support or guidance… Sometimes it feels impossible to see the positives & it’s NOT your fault. You don’t have to tackle these thoughts alone. Seeking help is incredibly brave. If you’re not sure where to start, here are some great services that may be able to support you:

Butterfly foundation national helpline - 1800 33 4673

Headspace - 1800 650 890

If you live outside Australia, check out checkpointorg.com/global for the support organisations in your country 💗

Happy Real Me Monday xo

we grow to believe the words we repeat to ourselves.

this is why negative self-talk is so powerful.

this is why positive self-talk is so powerful.

we have control over our own narrative.

positive self-talk helped me heal. for years i repeated short mantras to myself on a daily basis. words i believed were untrue but spoke to myself anyway. i remember crying alone in bathroom stalls in high school, telling myself i was strong, telling myself i was worthy of healing. i didn’t believe these sentiments at the time. but i spoke them anyway.

i remember standing in the mirror as a teen- always standing in the mirror. analyzing myself from every angle. criticizing the way my body folded and creased, where it held weight and the shapes it didn’t have. i told myself i loved my body for what it allowed me to do and not for how it looked. i didn’t believe these sentiments at the time. but i spoke them anyway.

we grow to believe the words we repeat to ourselves. today i know i am strong and worthy of healing. today i know i love my body for what it allows me to do and not for how it looks. i laid a foundation of positive self-talk for years. it is what grounds me today. i whole-heartedly believe in things i never thought could be true. 

consistency. repetition. commitment. 

self-love. self-respect. self-care.

these pictures are taken one year apart. aside from the fact that i’m still living in sweatshirts (🤠) a lot has changed.

when i posted the second photo last year, everything was unknown. i left school thinking i’d be home for a week or two. i had no idea how heavy the world would become for months, for a year. i had no idea that that my life as i knew it and the plans i had for the future would both be flipped upside down.

i remember taking that photo and feeling afraid. and i still am, afraid, sometimes. but hardship makes us stronger. i took the first photo today and felt changed. refreshed. like i’ve let go of so much.

this past year i’ve:

- finally closed doors on experiences that no longer serve me
- leaned deeply into relationships, and accepted that the need to be supported is not a weakness but a strength
- taken control over my own narrative, and chosen to see rejection as redirection
- worked on feeling secure in my person, my skin, and my beliefs

time heals. it really does. i think back to this time last year- i don’t have everything figured out now, but i have found peace in places where i never thought possible. i’ll always have work to do. we’re always healing. change doesn’t always have to be obvious or out loud. 

these pictures look similar but are deeply different. the internal work is the hardest. it’s also the most rewarding. this year has been tough but i’ve found room to grow.  i’m proud of that. i have ways to go but ive also come far. 

i’m excited to meet the person i’ll be next year, and the next, and the next 🦋🦋 taking a few minutes to reflect like this every so often is so healing for me 🙏

i woke up this morning and swung my feet over the side of my bed. they hit the ground and i was overcome with a crippling need for change. i can’t explain it any other way. a wave, washing over. it was only a few minutes later that i realized today’s date was september first. a coincidental, subconscious pull toward new beginnings.

a friend recently asked me where i believed my life was at in the current moment. am i at the beginning of a new chapter? in the midst of one? i replied that i feel so close to the end of a chapter but can’t seem to close it out. i feel as if i’ve done all the work possible in my power to turn a new page, but the deciding factor relies on forces out of my control. i feel a touch stuck, a bit defeated, and somewhat directionless.

this is hard to admit, but there’s strength in vulnerability. by recognizing these unsettling truths i can address them. i can see rejection as redirection. i can redefine concepts like “success”, “worth”, and “accomplishment”. i can begin to change little details in my life to feel something new, while i wait on the big changes to find their way to me.

this morning i replaced the set of necklaces i wear daily with a fresh new set. i picked up a non-fiction read to break my several-month long streak of fiction stories. i decided to try a new meal for breakfast, and added some stretches to my morning routine. these are simple ways to shake up my world, but they are adding up. 

as we move into fall i’m learning this season all over again. this is my first year out of school. my first year not returning to the life i’ve known for so long. i’m learning how to navigate this uncertain time. i’m learning to accept that i can’t control everything, and to not get frustrated so easily.

it’s a process, and it’s not easy, but it’s crucial.

.

.

.
in 2019 i challenged myself on all fronts; in my work, in my education, in my relationships and social life and, most importantly, in self-discovery. i grew a whole damn lot. as the year drifts off i feel a deeper sense of purpose. of pleasure. of power. .

2020, let’s do this. onto the next one.

The meeting was okay but I have to decide whether or not to go back to school and I don’t know what to do. I wanted to slee all day but I pushed myself to go on a walk instead. My friends and I got yelled at by another patient because we were reading the newspaper and he got angry of us for talking about trump and Iran because he’s a trump supporter. It was scary and now I’m scared to leave my room. I ended up staying in my room for most of the night and going to bed early. I got woken up to take my meds and then played cards with my friends for a bit.
document2: Day 57 of inpatient started out really shitty but got a lot better. I woke up late and went back to bed immediately after meeting with the weekend doctor and taking care of ADLs. My dogs were going to visit today but I got dropped a level bc of self harm and other stuff so they couldn’t come. That made me upset so I stayed in bed for the whole day shift and barely talked to anyone. I had a visitor and that was nice. My day started to get better after that. I spent the rest of the day playing games with friends and that was fun.
document3: Day 14 of inpatient was bad. I had a bad morning and slept until the afternoon. I had a bad evening too. My mood was really low and my anxiety was bad. I don’t know why things are getting worse. Oh well.
document4: Day 59 of inpatient was mixed. I didn’t sleep well last night (as usual) and I woke up feeling super anxious for no reason. They wouldn’t give me my anxiety meds because my blood pressure was too low and that made me more anxious. I slept for most of the morning but got out of bed for the afternoon. I played games and did puzzles and that was fun. The night got worse and I just feel like garbage.
document5: Day 13 of inpatient was bad. I got woken up early by my doctor and that put me in a bad mood. I was pretty anxious all day bc I had a pass with my parents. The pass went okay but I felt pretty crappy after. It was just a bad day.
document6: Day 12 of inpatient was mixed. The morning and afternoon weren’t great. I slept in late and didn’t go to many of the groups. I stayed in my room for a lot of the day and I had really bad anxiety for most of it. One of the other patients was yelling at the staff and kicking things and men yelling is a trigger for me so that was difficult. Things got a lot better at night. I spent time with my friends and with staff and it was just really fun and a nice distraction. It’s weird how normal things feel here. Sometimes I forget that I’m in a psych hospital.
document7: Day 10 of inpatient was ok. I woke up late and felt ok. A family friend visited and that was really nice. The day got worse after that and I just started feeling sad about all the things I’m missing out on. It just kind of all hit me that all my friends are doing things and living their lives and accomplishing things while I’m stuck here. I don’t know. It just bummed me out.
document8: Day 9 of inpatient was pretty bad. I woke up a lot later than usual because my anxiety medication made me really tired. I wasn’t able to go on any of the walks today because the staff didn’t think I was safe to go. They made me stay in open areas the whole day and I was so bored. My aunt and my parents visited and it didn’t go well. It was fine with my aunt but my parents said that I would have to pay for residential treatment. I was already having a bad depression day and that just made me feel worse. I already feel like a burden to them and that just made me feel bad. I was able to spend some time with friends and that made me feel better.
document9: Day 7 of inpatient started out really bad but got better at night. I got woken up by my treatment team and I was super groggy for awhile. A lot of shit went down today with other patients and some of it was triggering so my anxiety was bad. My depression was also really bad today and I spent most of the afternoon/evening in my room. I eventually felt a little better and hung out with my friends. We listened to music and played cards and ordered ice cream and it was fun. It’s my friend’s last night and I’m happy for her but it’s hard to see all my friends go home while I’m still here.
document10: Day 4 of inpatient was mostly good. I got moved up to level 2 so I was finally allowed to go on walks. I’m just having a lot of really negative thoughts and I can’t make them stop.

document7: Question: Obviously in the U.K. we are isolating at home but when looking at Sweden and South Korea, it’s potentially not the solution to self-isolate? I’m not saying it’s right or wrong either way but the U.K. needs to be mass testing like Sweden and South Korea. If we do that, life can begin to go back to “normal” - what do you think?  Answer: Mass testing would certainly help the situation, especially for frontline workers. It still wouldn’t change the fact that lots of us would still not be immune to the virus if it came our way, so I think there would still need to be a large degree of self isolating going alongside it. S Korea had a fairly specific situation in that the majority of its cases were clustered in a couple of centres. And I’m not sure Sweden is doing any better than the rest of the world, it still has a substantial number of cases - the most of any of the Scandinavian countries by numbers.But yes, I agree we need lots more testing - both testing for individuals to see if they have it now and testing for individuals to see if they have had it in the past. Even though we still don’t know for sure whether having had it in the past will make us immune from having it again, we just don’t know enough about the virus yet. The trouble seems to be that the tests aren’t yet widely available and/or adequately developed in the UK. And as Jenny Harries, the chief medical officer, said “The only thing worse than no test is a bad test”. Jumping in too soon with tests that aren’t reliable could have devastating consequences. The government is really coming under fire though for inadequate test numbers, so let’s see what today’s press conference brings. I think testing will be the hot topic.

Mini Upper Body Workout for Newbies in the Gym (like me) #workoutwithholly 💪🏻🔥
-
So here is my first little insta workout for you all. Using the machines and weights in the gym can be extremely intimidating at first, and I think one of the reasons is because we often don’t know how to use the machines! Therefore, as I’ve mentioned in previous posts, I want to hopefully show you guys how to use the different machines and what muscles you should be working.
-
These 4 exercise I did for 1 minute each, and repeated the whole circuit 4 times. This is a bit more of an unusual style, instead of say do a set number of reps. However personally, I prefer lifting a slightly lighter weight and doing more reps over a longer time period. It helps you get used to how the machine works, and I sometimes find that just doing one exercise at a time gets a bit boring!
-
Exercise 1 // Lat pull down // 1 minute
Focus on pulling your elbows in and down. This mostly works your lats, one of the largest muscles of the back, but you will also engage your biceps a bit as well.
Exercise 2 // Seated chest fly // 1 minute
Keep your arms slightly bent and shoulder blades pinned back.
Exercise 3 // Flat chest press // 1 minute
Don’t lock your elbows at the top, have a slight arch in your back and press your feet firmly against the ground. 
Exercise // 4 Low row // 1 minute
Pull your elbows in and back, and hold then the squeeze for a second or so to feel the burn.
-

#AshtangaMondays

I decided for these I want to focus on certain parts of the primary series, so this first part is the #SuryaNamaskara or the sun salutations A + B

SWIPE!! upward facing dog ➡️Surya Namaskara A (real time)➡️Surya Namaskara B(real time)➡️the rest of the sequence that my camera managed to get before it ran out of space

The Surya Namaskaras in the beginning of the sequence serves as both a warm up and a call to concentration for the rest of the practice. It builds foundational energy and also draws one to focus on the breath to warm up not only the insides but the outside of the body

5 rounds of A is then intensified by 5 rounds of B, which adds in Virabhadrasana (Warrior 1) on each side, then the body is ready to continue on

10 rounds of Sun Salutations might seem like a lot and maybe excessive, but I love it because sometimes I come onto the mat with my brain all over the place and sometimes I even miss a step or mindlessly breath. 5 of each Surya Namaskara seems to get my mind right back into coordinating movement with breath and at the end of it, I am dialed in to a conversation with the present moment.

A little post 10K run photoshoot because . . . why not? And of course, Bali and Java had to get involved. I was on such a high yesterday after finishing my last kilometre because I felt so good the whole way (which doesn’t always happen let me just say that first). But I was smiling to myself under the sun, I felt super energised, and I was honestly loving the podcast I was listening to all about vegan athletes.
-
Feeling super inspired, I thought I’d answer the question WHY I RUN 🏃🏻‍♀️ I want to film a ‘running story’ video and also a Q&A all about running (both are on my growing list of videos to film 🙈), but I thought I’d share just a few reasons here first.
-
001 // It’s a reason to go outdoors and get fresh air. Personally, the UK spring weather is usually optimal for me: not too hot, not too cold, a bit of a breeze. But whether the heat feels claustrophobic or my butt cheeks are hideously numb, it’s fresh air and that’s what matters most to me.
-
002 // Recently, I’m running with the half marathon in mind. And that means I’m working to beat my previous time, run faster, or run a longer distance. Challenging myself with running has made it so much more exciting and rewarding.
-
003 // I think everyone’s probably heard of endorphins. With any form of exercise you get that positive feeling afterwards, but for me, endorphins are on an all time high after I run.
-
004 // Stress relief. At my desk, there’s a million-and-one things going on inside my head all at the same time. Whilst on a run, it’s a chance for me to escape that chaotic bubble and just be in my own company.
-
005 // Running is for anyone and everyone. For sure you have to train pretty intensely to be a pro runner like Mo Farah, but it’s so easy to just put on some trainers and run. And simply run for fun. I also love running to explore and find new places, which is something I loved doing in Australia (except in Darwin . . . yeah, about that 😭🏥).
-
Happy Monday my friends. I hope this possibly gave you a small dose of inspo to maybe go on a run this week 💪🏻
